title: sore throat earache dr hilary
story: AS we come to the end of our second week in lockdown, many of you may be struggling with being cut off from the outside world. It can be hard knowing how best to protect yourself and your loved ones against coronavirus as it continues to spread.But Dr Hilary Jones – Health Editor for ITV’s Good Morning Britain – is here to answer YOUR concerns. We have already received more than , questions so far. Emma Pietras brings you the much-respected doctor’s answers to your dilemmas on how to help care for loved ones and look after your own health.Q. I keep getting a sore throat and earache. I’ve had breast cancer. Should I worry A. These symptoms are very common with the normal types of cold and flu viruses and are not typical of the symptoms of Covid-.Even though you have had breast cancer, there is no reason to believe your immune system is not now as strong as anybody ’s.Take paracetamol and throat lozenges — and try not to worry too much.Q. I have been self-isolating for ten days. If I still have a weird taste in my mouth and a sore throat, do I need to be concerned about going out next week, when my  days of self-isolation are over A. You should continue to self- isolate.Guidance says thatyou feel well but only have a cough after  days, you can safely resume normal activities.Butyou have ongoing symptoms, it would be sensible to extend your self-isolation.Q. My daughter is  weeks pregnant and her father-in-law is in an induced coma after testing positive for coronavirus. Can she and her husband get tested  They don’t live with him but they have delivered food.A. Unfortunately not.Tests are in short supply and are reserved for patients in respiratory failure being admitted to hospital as well as for the healthcare professionals who are treating them.The good news  There is no evidence that evenyour daughter has been exposed to the virus that she would be more at risk than anyone , or that the virus can be transmitted to the unborn baby.Q. My daughter has psoriasis and she recently stopped taking her immunosuppressants on the advice of her dermatologist. Is it possible that she would get more severe coronavirus symptoms because of her overactive immune system and,so, is she better off on immunosuppressants A. Your daughter is better off not taking immunosuppressants, as there is a theoretical risk this could reduce her response to the virusshe is exposed to it.Her skin condition can be treated with alternative topical medications which will not render her more at risk of the virus than anyone .Q. I am having a kidney stone operation next week. Should I self-isolate for seven days when home A. No, you should not need to self-isolate.If the op goes ahead, you will be kept well away from areas where Covid- patients are being treated.So unless you develop symptoms, you do not need to self isolate.Q. I had a stroke six years ago. Am I at a higher risk A. If you have made a full recovery, you are not more risk.However,you have any remaining disability which is affecting your breathing or mobility, you should take extra care, remain at home and practise physical distancing.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Q. title: flight tracker images show skies emptied coronavirus
story: The illustrations come before one of the world’s busiest airports - Heathrow - will next week close one of its runways, as air traffic continues to plummet globally.The images come from a Stratos Jet Charters analyst using data from Flightradar , an online global flight tracking service.They reveal stark dferences in skies above the UK, America, Australia, New Zealand and Europe before and after many countries brought in restrictions on international flights.After first breaking out in China, the coronavirus has spread across the globe, infecting more than one million people while about , have died.Among the many industries hit hard economically as a result, the passenger travel sector has been decimated by the pandemic.The world economic forum said the potent combination of in place, with many encouraging people to avoid non-essential travel even before Covid- was officially considered a pandemic by the World Health Organization .In London, Heathrow will operate its landings and takeoffs from one strip from Monday April  to increase resilience and safety for staff, passengers and cargo throughout the Covid- outbreak.The major airport has two runways and will alternate which one it keeps open on a weekly basis, a spokesman said.He added: Although we are seeing signicantly fewer flights at the moment, Heathrow will remain open so that we can continue to play a crucial role in helping to secure vital medical goods and food for the nation during this unprecedented epidemic.The earliest impacts of the coronavirus travel advisories were felt in February, as flight capacity in and out of China dropped sharply around Lunar New Year.Meanwhile in Europe, Italy saw a  per cent drop in flights coinciding with the announcement of a national lockdown on March .Now that the situation has intensied, flights to and from Italy have plummeted  per cent from their normal rates.On March , the US enforced a -day ban on travellers from the Schengen Area, a free-travel zone consisting of  countries in Europe.Although the UK and Ireland were initially exempt, the ban has since been extended to include both countries as well.Meanwhile, as of March , the US-Canada border is closed for all non-essential travel. This follows a previous announcement from the Canadian government that it would be curbing entry to only Canadian citizens, family members, permanent residents, diplomats, and Americans.The economic impact on airlines has been immense. Nearly  per cent of flights impacted by the European travel bans are US-based, such as Delta and United Airlines, with billions in lost revenue already estimated for this year, says the forum.Many airlines worldwide face the threat of bankruptcy in coming months,these declining trends continue. To hedge against these domino effects of the outbreak, US airlines are requesting upwards of billion in bailouts and direct assistance from the government.Covid- is throwing everything up in the air - including the fate of airline companies, it adds.Reuters reported on March  that airlines across the globe are feeling the pain as travel demand withers because of the coronavirus outbreak, scrapping flights and ditching financial forecasts.The global health crisis has brought European air travel to a standstill, leaving airlines with no revenue and facing a struggle for survival.Air France-KLM said on March  it would park its biggest airliners and slash services by up to  per cent. The group said it had identied measures to save  million eurosin  and ways to cut its capital expenditure by  million euros.Air New Zealand said on March  it would cut long-haul capacity by  per cent in the coming months and the domestic network by  per cent in April and May.American Airlines plans to cut  per cent of its international flights through May  and ground nearly all its widebody fleet.Delta is cutting domestic capacity by ten to  per cent, and international by  to  per cent, freezing hiring, offering voluntary leave options to staff and looking at early retirement of older aircraft.In an effort to raise much-needed revenue and keep some planes in the air, Delta and Air New Zealand said they had joined the growing number of carriers offering cargo charters on passenger planes.We are getting some strong interest from customers wanting to ship to and from Shanghai, Hong Kong, San Francisco, Los Angeles, Sydney and Melbourne, Air New Zealands GM Cargo Rick Nelson said.Around half the worlds air cargo normally travels inside passenger planes rather than dedicated freighters, so the cancellation of passenger flights has led to a sharp reduction in cargo capacity. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: man ostrich skirting board
story: Danny Moss, from Wigan, Greater Manchester, took a picture of the big bird and posted it on on Facebook.He found the emu image in a plank of wood in his new skirting board.The ostrichs eyes, beak and neck can be seen staring out as Danny joked about going to a DIY store to replace the .Danny wrote: Is Wickes still open  Ive found a f****** ostrich in my new skirting board.His post has been shared hundreds of times on social media.People queued up to poke fun at Dannys lelike ostrich image.One man posted: Wickes have some neck selling that.Another said: I give it another week in isolation before that is cut out, marinated and bunged in the oven!And a third joked: Make it a feature.A fourth said: Or long neck ET.Ostriches are the biggest birds in the world, but cant fly.They can grow up to nine feet tall and can weigh up to  pounds.The big birds are native to Africa, and live on the savanna and desert.But they are also farmed for their meat in the UK and USA.They have excellent eyesight and can evade predators by running fast, hitting speeds of up to mph and covering  metres in one stride.They cant build nests in trees so lay their eggs in holes in the ground.But they bury their heads in the nests to rotate the eggs so they are evenly heated.The nearest real-le ostriches to Dannys are believed to be at Chester Zoo,  miles from Wigan.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: aching muscles sign most serious coronavirus cases
story: ACHING muscles could be sign of most serious coronavirus cases, doctors are warning. US researchers say Covid- patients with severe muscle soreness will be hit the hardest by the virus - and usually go on to develop severe respiratory disease.Currently, the NHS only lists a new, continuous cough and a high temperature as the two main signs of the new coronavirus.Researchers at New York Universityfound the link between aching muscles and severe cases of Covid- by analysing records from  hospitalised patients in Wenzhou, China.Most of the participants were in their s or s, and nearly two-thirds were men.Megan Coffee, an infectious-disease clinician and lead author of the study, told Business Insider that they carried out the study to assist doctors in that first stage to be able to identy who may become sick of the many mild cases.One of the main signs they found in those with severe lung disease was deep muscle aches, known clinically as myalgia.Myalgia can involve ligaments, tendons and fascia, the soft tissues that connect muscles, bones and organs.Myalgia has also previously been linked to higher general inflammation in the body.And according to the World Health Organization, about  per cent of all coronavirus patients experienced body aches or joint pain.The aches are triggered by chemicals called cytokines - which the body releases while responding to the infection.As well as muscle soreness, the researchers found that changes in levels of the liver enzyme alanine aminotransferaseand haemoglobin levels were also key predictors of whether iniduals would go on to develop severe respiratory disease. To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.ALT is normally found inside liver cells, however, when your liver is damaged or inflamed, ALT can be released into your bloodstream.High levels of ALT in a person’s blood can signal the presence of liver damage or inflammation.And haemoglobin is a protein that transports oxygen through the blood.In patients severely ill with coronavirus, the red blood cell production increases to make up for chronically low blood oxygen levels due to poor lung .The experts added that determining whether a patient is likely to get worse could help hospitals decide which cases to monitor.Hospitals are just so overstretched thatsomeone doesn’t immediately need oxygen they may not be able to find a place for them, Coffee said.But they might be able to say, ‘You really need to check back in tomorrow.Doctors could then treat a patient before their case becomes critical, lessening the burden on the NHS.Anasse Bari, a clinical assistant professor at NYU who co-authored the study, added: We’re not by any means trying to replace doctors’ decisions.We just want to arm doctors with tools to see quicklythis is a severe case and predict outcomes.Yesterday it was revealed that coronavirus could invade the brain directly in rare circumstances, causing inflammation.Researchers have seen patients develop acute necrotising encephalitis- a central nervous infection.ANE is a rare disease characterised by brain damagethat usually follows a viral infection.It’s previously been linked to infections like the flu, chickenpox and enterovirus - but now doctors believe could also be associated with the new coronavirus.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: matt hancock coronavirus glass throat weight
story: MATT Hancock today appeared to struggle with a cold after coming back to work from battline coronavirus - as he revealed hes lost half a stone.The Health Secretary was diagnosed with the virus last week, but attended the opening of the NHS Nightingale today after a week of self-isolating.The Health Secretary appeared to have a bit of a croak in his throat at last nights Downing Street briefing - where he unveiled a new five-point plan to ramp up testing.Earlier today he was photographed blowing his nose into a tissue - in a sign he may still be a bit under the weather.UK medical advice says that anyone should self isolate for seven days after they first get symptoms - and even longerthey still feel unwell or have a high temperature.Speaking this morning, he explained the illness left him struggling to sleep and unable to eat for days.He said: “It was a pretty unpleasant experience“I went downhill on Thursday last week and for a couple of nights it was very hard to sleep, incredibly painful throat, like having glass in my throat.“When you’re on the way down it’s really worrying because we can all see just how serious this illness is.“I’ve lost half a stone. It’s quite a serious impact directly.“But thankfully for me I could get through it, and I managed to keep working through it.”His comments come one day on from demanding Premier League stars do their bit over coronavirus and take a pay cut.Several clubs are making staff take massive pay cuts, but refusing to cut the multi-million pound salaries of their players during the crisis.This includes a host of top clubs such as Tottenham, Newcastle, Bournemouth and Norwich.Speaking yesterday, the Health Secretary warned football clubs everyone needs to do their bit in the battle against the virus.He said: That means Premier League footballers too.The first thing they can do is make a contribution, take a pay cut and play their part.He also pledged to test , Brits a day for coronavirus after the shambles of recent days – but it won’t be for weeks to come.As the Health Secretary’s voice croaked after he came back from fighting the virus himself, he revealed a new plan to tackle the deadly bug with a huge ramping up of tests.Another  people were confirmed to have died of Covid- yesterday – taking the UK total to more than ,.His five point plan to get to , tests a day by the end of April included:All NHS staff will be able to have a test by the end of the month, he promised.“That is the goal and I’m determined were going to get there,” Mr Hancock insisted.The NHS states the key coronavirus symptoms to watch for are a new, continuous and dry cough as well as a high temperature.Experts have called for a loss of taste and smell to be recognised on that list, by Chief Medical Officer Chris Whitty, after scientists found  per cent of people with the virus displayed those signs.Other symptoms reported by patients include muscle aches, sore throat, tummy aches and diarrhoea and nasal congestion.To follow us on Facebook, simply Like our Coronavirus page.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.

title: coronavirus spread just talking breathing
story: CORONAVIRUS could be spread just by breathing and talking, doctors are warning. Experts have previously said the deadly bug is transmitted between people through droplets spread from coughing and sneezing.And those droplets can contaminate surfaces or objects and infect people who touch the surface and then touch their faces.However, scientists are now warning that coronavirus may also spread through the air in tiny particles that infected people exhale during normal breathing and speech.Researchers from the US National Academies of Sciencemade the revelation in a report they delivered to the White House on Wednesday.According to CNN, the letter, written by Dr. Harvey Fineberg, a former Hard School of Public Health dean, emphasised that even the breath of a person with coronavirus could be dangerous.He said: While the current [coronavirus] specic research is limited, the results of available studies are consistent with aerosolization of virus from normal breathing.The NAS letter to the White House noted research conducted in a Chinese hospital that found the virus can sent into the air and linger there when health care workers take of their protective gear and possibly as result of cleaning jostling the particles free, or even of movements.If coronavirus is airborne, that could help to explain why it is so contagious, and can spread before people have symptoms.As of yesterday, more than one million people are confirmed to have Covid-, and more than , people have died worldwide.In the UK, there are , cases of coronavirus - and the death toll stands at ,.And over in the US there , confirmed cases and , deaths.Brits are currently advised to stay more than two metres apart from one another to slow the spread of coronavirus, however, Dr Fineberg warned that the virus can spread much further.He said: If you generate an aerosol of the virus with no circulation in a room, its conceivable thatyou walk through later, you could inhale the virus.Butyoure outside, the breeze will likely disperse it.Dr Fineberg and his expert  said that wearing surgical masks can cut down on the amount of virus that infected people spread - citing an unpublished study from the University of Hong Kong.However, their letter does not address whether wearing a mask will protect the person wearing the mask from catching the illness and how much virus a person must breathe in to get infected isn’t known.Dr Fineberg said he himself will begin wearing a mask in public as a precaution against contracting the virus, especially in relatively closed spaces like grocery stores.He added: Im not going to wear a surgical mask, because clinicians need those.But I have a nice western-style bandana I might wear. Or I have a balaclava. I have some pretty nice options.Yesterday it was revealed Brits could soon be ordered to wear a face mask in public after new evidence prompted officials to consider a major U-turn.World Health Organisation advisers examined research that suggests their wider use does help to combat coronavirus.The review may lead the WHO and the UK government to rewrite existing guidelines, which only recommend their use in limited circumstances.Washing your hands with soap and water for at least  seconds and social distancing are still the best way to stop the deadly new virus from spreading.The NHS has until now maintained there is “very little evidence” of their benefit outside of hospital but masks are compulsory in some countries.Prof David Heymann, who chairs the advisory group, said new data from Hong Kong and the USA had led to the review.He said: “There is right now a debate about the usefulness of masks because Hong Kong has provided some evidence that masks may be useful in protecting iniduals from infection.“It’s not clear yet whether or not that’s true.“The WHO, the group that I work with, is debating that with a group of experts from around the world to understand whether there is evidence which would call for a change in what WHO is recommending.”Some experts have warned there is an increased risk of infectionpeople do not use face masks correctly or take care when removing them.Others have said they can protect people from catching the virus and stop infected people from passing it on.The WHO has said people only need to wear masksthey are caring for someone with Covid-, orthey themselves are coughing or sneezing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bernie ecclestone jokes practise dad again
story: The Formula  boss revealed his we Fabiana Flosi, , is pregnant with a baby boy - due in July.The new arrival will be the grandfather-of-fives first son and will arrive just shy of his th birthday.And billionaire Bernie, who already has three daughters, said he was ready for the new addition to his family.He pointed out he had taken a step back from the world of Formula  and motorsports - meaning he had lots of time on his hands.Bernie last night told the Daily Mail: Theres nothing that unusual is there  I havent had a job for a little while so I have had plenty of time to practise!The couple are currently self-isolating at their home in Sao Paulo, Brazil, amid the coronavirus.Pregnant women have been warned to take extra precautions during the pandemic - classed as vulnerable.Announcing the news, Bernie said: Yes, it is due in the summer. Hopefully he’ll learn to play backgammon soon!Fabiana told Swiss newspaper Blick: “Like all parents we have only one wish: the child must be born healthy.“Hopefully he will never express any interest in doing something in Formula !”Bernie currently has three children - Deborah, , Tamara, , and Petra, .The eccentric business mogul has amassed an estimated fortune of £.billion from his involvement in Formula .He has had three marriages - to Ivy Bamford, model Slavica Radic and his current we Fabiana.He married marketing director Ms Flosi in  - three years after he orced Croatian model Ms Radic.The couple met through the World Motor Sport Council in around .Mr Eccelstone was born the son of a fisherman in Suffolk in  and after WWII got his first job at a gasworks testing gas purity.His first involvement in motorsport was trading spare parts for motorcycles before he branched into car racing in , driving Formula  series cars.Following an accident he withdrew from racing cars himself.After making successful investments in property he ed to motorsport in a management role making his first entry into Formula .He was involved in team ownership until  when he formed the Constructors Association in  and became its chief executive four years later.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: human remains found north yorkshire moors
story: Cops have been searching the isolate home after reportedly unearthing the bones of two people buried in the garden.They are now working with a forensic archaeologist after the grisly discovery was made this week in Chop Gate, near the edge of the North Yorkshire moors.A spokesperson for North Yorkshire Police confirmed there had been no arrests at this time.They added: Police are working with other agencies, including a forensic archaeologist, following the discovery of suspected human bones at a remote location near Chop Gate.“Although it is too early to say precisely how old these bones are, current forensic investigations suggest that they are not recent, and are likely to be several decades old.Specialists are being used to recover and examine them.“We’d ask people not to speculate online about the nature of the bones while this process is underway.”Chop Gate is a tiny village in the heart of the North Yorkshire Moors boasting just one pub and a church.It is close to the highest point of the national park and is a popular spot for walkers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: corona beer production suspended coronavirus
story: CORONA beer production has been suspended due to the coronavirus pandemic sparking fears of a worldwide shortage.The previously popular lager, whose coincidentally named brand has since a decline in sales since the coronavirus outbreak, will not be produced after Mexico deemed it non-essential.Grupo Modelo said on Thursday it will temporarily stop brewing Corona beer and other brands exported to  countries after its business activities were declared non-essential under a government order aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus.The brewery said it was scaling down its operations to a bare minimum in line with the Mexican governments orders but suggested it could keep brewing beerits operations were deemed to be agriculture.Agriculture and food production are among the key sectors which are still allowed tounder Mexican government orders.The brewer said in a statement: If the federal government considers it appropriate to issue some clarication confirming beer as an agro-industrial product, at Grupo Modelo we are ready to execute a plan with more than  per cent of our staff working from home and at the same time guaranteeing the supply of beer.Grupo Modelo operates  breweries in Mexico and said the suspension will go into place from Sunday.The brewery will reduce operations to a level where they could resume once the suspension is ltedMexico has so far registered more than , confirmed cases of coronavirus and  deaths.Non-essential activities have been suspended for at least the month of April to slow the spread of coronavirus.Mexicos other major beer producer Heineken - which makes the Tecate and Dos Equis brands - could also stop activities on Friday, Mexican media said.The northern state of Nuevo Leon where Heinekens Mexican operations are based said on Wednesday it would stop the distribution of beer, sparking panic-buying.The company suffered another blow last week when plans for a .billion brewery on the U.S. border were rejected in a referendum.The plant was already two-thirds built but Mexicos government said it would not grant operating permits after the vote.Anheuser-Busch InBev, the brewer of Corona and other beers, said last month it believes it has lost  million in profits due to the coronavirus outbreak.The massive lost sales over the last few months coincides with the rising concern over the disease. The multinational drink and brewing company is based in Belgium, but have offices around the world, including in London and New York.It produces the Corona brand as well as Budweiser and Stella Artois.Corona is the third most popular beer in the US behind Guinness and Heineken, according to rankings by the market research company YouGov.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: teachers homework coursework exam grades
story: Exam boards will write to all schools after Easter to set out what teachers need to do to give students their results after exams were binned over the coronavirus crisis.They will have to send to the regulator the grades they believe the students were on track to getthey had sat the exams, and then rank all of their students in order of how well they think they have done.That data has to be sent off by the end of May, and Ofqual will then use that to standardise the grades across the board.Schools and colleges can use homework, class assignments and any mock exams to help them come to a conclusion about what award they will get.The regulator has written to all students letting them know whats happening too.And results will come out even earlier than the August expected time too, they said today.But no student will be able to find out the grades teachers have recommended for them in advance.The news will mean -year-olds should be able to go on to university as planned, and kids sitting GCSEs will be able to move up to collegethey want to.Exam boards will offer more formal tests in the autumn to make up for anyone who wants to sit their exam later too.The system will apply for GCSEs, AS and A Levels, and Extended Project Qualications .Sally Collier, Chief Regulator, Ofqual, said today: School or college-based assessment already has an important role in many GCSEs, AS and A levels, and in extraordinary circumstances such as these, schools and colleges are best placed to judge the likely performance of their students at the end of the course.We have worked closely with the teaching profession to ensure that what we are asking is both appropriate and manageable, so that everyone can have confidence in the approach.I would like to take this opportunity to thank teachers and school leaders for making this process work for students during these very challengingWe have published a message to students to reassure them that we, and exam boards, will do everything we can to make sure that, as far as possible, grades are fair and that they are not disadvantaged in their progress to sixth form, college, university, apprenticeships, training or work because of these unprecedented conditions. The news comes today as the Government revealed it had worked with the BBC on a new education programme to be broadcast across the nation during the crisis. weeks of education programmes will go out to every household in the land thanks to the partnership, which will help kids to learn for the next term.Culture Secretary Oliver Dowden said today: Working with Govt, the @BBC has announced a massive education programme to ensure kids at home keep learning over the next school term.Public Service Broadcasting at its very core.Coming to our [homes] from  April.The news is a sign that schools wont be open again until at least September.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lent end date easter give up
story: MANY think of Lent as a time to give up something, such as chocolate or alcohol, but its also an important event in the Christian calendar.Let’s take a closer look at why it is so important and why people give up one of their vices during this time...Lent is the six week period leading up to Easter Sunday.The actualis  days – however,  of these are fasting days and six are Sundays.Sundays in Lent are not counted in the forty days because each Sunday represents a mini-Easter.The period of Lent is seen as a time of solemn observance and preparation for the celebration of the death and resurrection of Jesus at Easter.From its start on Ash Wednesday until its official conclusion on Maundy Thursday, Lent has been a traditional time for fasting, giving something up, or abstinence.The word Lent comes from the Anglo Saxon word lencten, which means spring.The forty days represent the time Jesus spent in the wilderness, enduring the temptation of Satan and preparing to begin his ministry.It can also be seen to mirror the  hours that Jesus spent in the tomb prior to his resurrection.Lent will began on Ash Wednesday – which in  was February .Lent lasts  days with the Sundays seen as celebrations and not counted.It officially ends on Maundy Thursday, which is April , .Good Friday is also traditionally a day of fasting and penance.However, most people who have given things up for Lent, choose to carry on until Easter Sunday. Many Christians will use Lent to commit to fasting, choosing to abstain from certain foods, habits or vices.The fasting and abstinence is meant to mirror the experience of Jesus Christ and his experience of fasting in the desert.Traditionally, Christians would fast during the  days of Lent, meaning they would have only one full meal a day and two small snacks.However, nowadays Christians choose to abstain from something in particular – like a food item or luxury like chocolate or caffeine, or a particular habit like drinking or smoking.In today’s technological age, others choose to give up social media or even using their phones.Generally, those observing Lent will also aim to perform one positive act for each of the days between Ash Wednesday and Easter Sunday.These positive acts can include calling up someone who is alone, donating to a worthy cause, clearing up after dinner and letting someone go ahead of you in a supermarket queue.Oryou dont know what to do, you can sign up to website  acts of kindness, which will send you an email each day featuring deeds such as bless the boss, give blood or clean the kitchen at work.It kinda makes sense!Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: bus companies handed 167m coronavirus
story: NewsBus companies handed £m coronavirus bailout to keep services runningPassenger numbers have plummeted - but services need to keep running to get key workers to their jobShareCommentsByBen GlazeDeputy Political Editor:,  APR NewsPassenger numbers have plummeted since Boris Johnson ordered people to stay at home" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Bus companies have been handed a £million bailout to keep vital services running during the coronavirus crisis. Passenger numbers have plummeted since Boris Johnson ordered people to stay at home, with only “key workers” allowed to travel during the Covid- lockdown.The huge drop in commuters has piled pressure on operators. But ministers are desperate for buses to stay on the roads to ferry staff to shops, hospitals and other essential workplaces – and for people who need to travel to buy food. Announcing the latest Government bailout, Transport Secretary Grant Shapps said: “We have been very clear during the outbreak that the best way to stop the spread of the virus and protect the NHS is to stay at homepossible. “Our buses are a leline for people who need to travel for work or to buy food – including our emergency services and NHS staff – and it’s absolutely vital we do all we can to keep the sector running. “This multimillion-pound investment will protect crucial local transport links across England, bolstering the sector and minimising disruption for passengers in the long term.”  The Bus Services Support Grant will be paid over three months and comes on top of £million already being poured into buses. Some £million which had been earmarked for new services will instead go to councils to maintain existing services – taking the total amount for buses to nearly £million. However, bus services were hammered during a decade of austerity.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email The exam watchdog has written to all students due to take A levels and GCSES after this year’s exam season was cancelled due to coronavirus.Students will receive grades based on their teachersapos assessment of their work, with the exam boards providing external checking. Sally Collier, Chief Regulator, Ofqual, said: “We have published a message to students to reassure them that we, and exam boards, will do everything we can to make sure that, as far as possible, grades are fair and that they are not disadvantaged in their progress to sixth form, college, university, apprenticeships, training or work because of these unprecedented conditions.” How will grades be calculated  Teachers will be asked to send exam boards two sets of data: . The grade they believe a student would most likely getteaching, learning and exams had happened as planned. Within each subject, the order of students, by performance, for each grade.This information will be used to standardise grades. Schools are being asked to consider a range of things including classwork and homework, results in assignments and any mock exams, any non-exam assessment or coursework and the studentaposs general progress during the course in order to decide the grade. Schools will be asked to sign to say that the data they are sending is correct. The exam board will then use the two forms of data submitted to decide the grade. Will students be told of their grades in advance  No. This is highly confidential.Teachers are told not to share this under any circumstances.Ofqual say it will avoid school leaders and staff being “put under pressure by students and parents, to submit a grade that is not supported by the evidence”. The grade that students eventually receive may not be the same as the grades the teachers put into the process. When do schools and colleges have to submit this information  The guidance is that it is not earlier than the  May. This will give the exam boards time to adapt to receiving lots of information they donapost normally handle. Exam boards will write to schools and colleges after Easter and they will have two weeks to submit that data. Should teachers set more work ahead of that deadline  Schools have also been told not to set extra work to inform the predictions, because young people may not be able to do themselves justicethey are incapacitated by illness or have a dficult home environment. When will results be published  No later than they were planned to be announced - but they could come earlierpossible.  Ofqual are confident that the moderation process will correct any over-inflation. Can students take exams laterthey prefer to do so  Ofqual says they are working with exam boards to seethey can provide exams in the Autumn. This might be particularly helpful for private candidates. story: NewsGovernment plans immunity passports for people to escape coronavirus lockdownBut health experts have warned that it may take  days for an immunity test to work and there is still uncertainty about whether or not immunity will last.ShareCommentsByNicola BartlettPolitical Correspondent:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsAntibody tests are still being tested to seethey work " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe government is looking at immunity passports for people who had the disease to be able to escape lockdown. But health experts have warned that it may take  days before an immunity test will work and that immunity may not last forever. It came as Health Secretary Matt Hancock pledged to ramp up the number of tests - to seepeople currently have the disease - to , a day by the end of April. The government has been on the backfoot over its testing commitments for several days now failing to explain why the UK lags behind its European counterparts - testing just , a day compared to , in Germany. Today Mr Hancock said that the government was looking at an immunity certicate as a way out of the lockdown imposed on the UK in the last two weeks. He told a press conference in Downing Street: How people who have had the disease have got the antibodies and therefore have the immunity can show that and so get back as much as possible to normal le. That is an important thing that we will be doing and are looking at. But the Health Secretary said it was too early in the science of the immunity that comes from having the disease to be clear about when that might come and how it would work. He added: I wish that we could but the reason that we canapost is because the science isnapost yet advanced enough. But we have a programme of work on to understand the immunity that you get out of this, which is a global piece of work. And what you then do for people who have had the disease.  Mr Hancock, who appeared in Downing Street for the first time in a week after self isolating, said: Believe you me I have a very strong, personal interest in this one now that Iaposve been through it. Public Health Englandaposs Director of Health Improvement Professor John Newton agreed that there was still a lot of work to be done to explore how immunity to coronavirus works. He said that getting antibody tests ready was less pressing than testing to seepeople currently have covid- - partly because of the time it takes for antibodies to show up.  He said: The initial priority is for the swab tests, because those are the tests that allow the NHS to manage critically ill patients to the best they possibly can and also to allow NHS staff and other key workers to come back to work when they can. The antibody tests are ideally done  days after an infection, so in fact the requirement for the antibody test isnapost really with us yet. Both types of test are important, both are urgent, but the most urgent is the swab test so we can treat patients better and get staff back to work.  He added: The test measures your immunity and the peak of your immunity is at  days. Soyou want to tell somebody that they havenapost been infected, and theyaposre not immune, you really have to do it then to be sure.  So thataposs the point about  days. Professor Newton also explained that scientists did not yet know how immunity would work. He said that what the test measures is an antibody, so there is some immunity. But the question of whether that is enough to stop you being infected at all, or getting serious disease is something that weaposre going to need to discover as time goes on. I think we have to be optimistic that it will give some immunity, but weaposre just not quite sure how much at the moment.

title: jeremy corbyns divided legacy how
story: NewsopinionJeremy Corbyns ided legacy - how Labours left-wing leader will be rememberedHe never expected to get the top job. And after his surprise win, he went on to transform the Labour Party into a mass movement. But he failed to win over the electorateShareCommentsByJason BeattieHead of politics:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsopinionOn the one measure that matters – the winning of power – he failed comprehensively. But Jeremy Corbyns legacy is more complex " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThis week Jeremy Corbyn steps down after five years as Labour leader. He ran for the top job never expecting to win and went on to oversee one of the most tumultuous and controversial chapters in his partyaposs history. On the one measure that matters – the winning of power – he failed comprehensively, losing two general elections. Many in the Labour will want to write his time in charge out of the history books. Others will claim he transformed his party and gave Labour back its soul. So how did he fare    If the purpose of a political party is to win power then Labour failed abjectly under Corbyn.Although he surprised his detractors in the general election, Labour was still  seats short of the majority needed to govern.The  election was even worse which saw Corbyn lead his party to its worse result since .The dismal run of form also saw Labour lose  seats in  local elections and  in the  local elections.Party management From the beginning Corbyn struggled to impose his command on the Parliamentary Party.He only scraped on to the ballot paper after MPs loaned him their vote to aposbroaden the debate.apos Few thought he would win. Having been a serial rebel under previous leaders he lacked the authority to whip his own backbenchers into line. In  dozens of frontbenchers resigned prompting an abortive leadership challenge led by Owen Smith. The party membership rallied behind their leader but it left Labour bruised and ided. And the warring continued at a local level as Corbyn supporters tried to deselect MPs who were deemed disloyal to the cause. Anti-semitism  Corbynaposs failure to tackle anti-Semitism is by far the biggest stain on his leadership. Labour became the second party after the BNP to be investigated by the Equality and Human Rights Commission for failing to root out anti-Jewish hate. Apologists for the Labour leader said the number of cases of proven anti-semitism was a fraction of the party membership. But Corbyn was too slow to stamp down on the hatred and abuse by supporters acting in his name. The failure saw Jewish MPs such as Louise Ellman and Luciana Berger driven from the party and the Chief Rabbi warn that Jewish people would not be safeLabour won power under Corbyn. Corbyn is rightly praised for empathy for those who have been hard done by but he often appeared to be out of touch with voters, including many traditional Labour voters, who like the flag, forces and family – they are patriotic, proud of the Armed Forces and fond of the Royals. Fairly or unfairly he was accused early on in his leadership of failing to sing the National Anthem.For many voters the defining moment was his response to the Skripal poisonings when he was initially reluctant to blame the Russians.By the time of the  election his personal approval ratings were the lowest recorded by an opposition leader. Struggled with Brexit  Any Labour leader would have found it dficult to plot a path through the thickets of the Brexit debate. As a lelong Eurosceptic, Corbyn found himself out of step not just with the majority of his MPs but the pro-EU party membership. In trying to keep the party together he ended up with a compromise position that pleased almost no one. In the December  he undermined his credentials as a conviction politician by promising a second referendum while refusing to say which way he would vote. Transformed Labour The Labour Corbyn bequeaths the new leader is very dferent to the one he inherited. The triangulation of the Tony Blair years which saw the party shadow many Tory economic policies was ditched for a more radical, socialist agenda. Corbyn and his supporters campaigned on an ambitious, some would argue too ambitious, manesto that pledged to renationalise swathes of the economy, scrap tuition fees and invest in schools, health and education.Whoever wins the leadership is unlikely to turn back the clock.Built a mass membership party When Corbyn became leader in  Labouraposs membership stood at ,. Five years later and can now boast more than , members – one of the largest political movements in the world. This mass membership has given Labour an army of supporters on the ground and brought in vital funds. Many of those who joined were young people who were energised by Corbynaposs message of change. But it has also caused tensions at a local level with more radical members finding themselves at odds with long-standing supporters from the Tony Blair and Gordon Brown years. Championed the underdog Corbyn won the leadership promising a “gentler, kinder, politics.” While not all his followers lived up to this ideal, the party leader won plaudits for the way he spoke up for those in hardship His citing of real peopleaposs experiences at Prime Ministeraposs Questions was further proof of his wish to do politics dferently. Tory MPs often scoffed when he championed welfare claimants or spoke up for bus travellers but the showed Corbyn had a better grasp of le outside Westminster than many gave him credit for. This was especially the case when he comforted the victims of the Grenfell fire in , showing an empathy Theresa May failed to display.

The next Labour leader will be unveiled by party bosses by email on Saturday after a special conference was scrapped as the coronavirus outbreak worsened. Shadow Brexit Secretary Keir Starmer is widely tipped to become the th leader of the Labour Party, beating rivals Rebecca Long-Bailey and Lisa Nandy. Mr Corbyn announced he was quitting after leading the party to its worst election showing since the s in December’s snap general election - leaving the Tories with an -strong majority. The winner of the deputy leadership race to take over from Tom Watson, expected to be shadow education secretary Angela Rayner, will be announced at the same time. Front-runner Mr Starmer thanked his rivals for showing “positivity and unity” as ballots closed in the three-month long contest. In a video message to his supporters, he said: “It’s been a long campaign and it’s ending in circumstances that none of us could have predicted”. He added that the race had demonstrated “to our party, to our movement and hopefully to the country that real good can come out of this election”. The latest survey from pollsters YouGov showed that Mr Starmer had a commanding lead over his rivals and could win on first preference votes among more than , members, affiliates and supporters.  Among those casting their votes were , new members who had joined since Labour’s catastrophic general election defeat. The new Labour leader would then immediately turn all the Opposition’s energy on helping tackle the coronavirus crisis. His supporters hope that his serious and forensic style will help hold the Government to account. But allies have ruled out him joining a national unity government - suggesting that Boris Johnson would only offerhe wanted to pin some of the fall-out from the coronavirus crisis onto Labour. Shadow health secretary Jonathan Ashworth, who has been Labour’s key voice during the pandemic, would be expected to be kept in post.  If Mr Starmer wins the contest he is likely to unveil his shadow cabinet team this weekend. It’s quite a serious impact directly. “But thankfully for me I could get through it, and I managed to keep working through it. But it’s obviously much harder when you’re both working from home and not very well.”  Boris Johnson was due to come out of self-isolation today, seven days after he came down with symptoms.But the Prime Minister could be forced to stay isolated in the Downing Street flat for longer, after he continued to show mild symptoms that hadnapost abated yesterday.  Mr Hancock insisted he felt entirely better. It came as the Health Secretary faced scrutiny over his pledge to ramp up testing for Covid- to , a day by the end of April. In the small print of his announcement, he admitted the , includes both antigen tests - which showyou currently have the virus - and antibody tests.  Antibody tests showyouaposve had the virus in the past and might be immune. Theyaposre useful, but havenapost been approved yet may only work  days or more after infection and arenapost as immediately needed. The previous target of , tests a day was just antigen tests. Mr Hancock cast more doubt on the programme today when he admitted he couldnapost guarantee he would get to , tests a day by the end of April.  BBC Breakfast asked him: Can you guarantee this is going to happen  He replied: “Yes, it’s got to happen” The presenter cut in: No, it’s *going* to happen  Mr Hancock said: “I’ve got a plan to get us there. I’ve set it as a goal.” The Health Secretary refused to give a guarantee because he said there were many “pieces of this puzzle” including the NHS, existing tech companies, new companies and university labs.

title: what next new labour leader
story: NewsopinionWhat next for the new Labour leader - challenges and a historic crisisThe winner will have to both unite a bitterly ided party during the coronavirus - but also convince Labour voters and the wider public that it can trust the party againShareCommentsByPippa CrerarDaily Mirror Political Editor:,  APR NewsopinionLabour leadership candidates Rebecca Long-Bailey, Lisa Nandy and Sir Keir Starmer " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - politicsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailKeir Starmer is expected to become Labour’s new leader tomorrow. But he faces a challenge not shared by any of his predecessors since Clement Attlee in the s.  The winner will have to rebuild a movement shattered by a historic election defeat which left Boris Johnson’s Tories with an -seat majority.  Alongside his focus on party unity will be a bigger priority: proving to voters that Labour can be trusted to run the country again.   But even that will have to wait.  With the coronavirus crisis gripping Britain, Starmer -he beats rivals Rebecca Long-Bailey and Lisa Nandy - will have to navigate his way through the weeks and months ahead. While the leadership contest has rumbled on, a partial void has opened up where the Opposition should be.  The new Labour chief must offer serious and forensic opposition to a Government that is struggling both to protect the NHS frontline and the most economically vulnerable.  But he must tread carefully between holding ministers to account and being seen to play politics with the biggest crisis facing Britain in a generation.  If he manages to do that he will have cemented himself in the public mind as a credible and caring alternative to the Tory administration.  It is years until the next election, so he has time on his side.  Internally, the new leader must sharpen up the party - clearing out some of the old guard and dramatically professionalising the operation.  He must deliver on his promises to the Jewish community with tough and decisive action to show that Labour will no longer tolerate anti-Semitism within its ranks.  But his biggest challenge will be whether he can genuinely bring his bitterly ided party together, persuading the Corbyn disciples and those who hanker after the Blair and Brown years to put their dferences aside. Many on both sides fear he can’t - and believe he will ultimately end up opting for one side or the other.  At the same time, the new leader must look outwards and show the country that Labour is ready for power.  Thousands of Labour voters lost trust in the party at the last election - over Brexit, the scale of its manesto, patriotism and - crucially - over Corbyn himself.  It will be a hard task to win that back. Starmer already knows that he needs to listen to voters - not just in the Northern heartlands but across the South, Scotland and the rest of the country too.

title: zoom whatsapp facebook live lockdown
story: AdvertorialBest ways people are using Zoom, Whatsapp and Skype video chats while on lockdownPeople are getting creative to keep in touch and charities - including these examples supported by The Health Lottery - are full of ideasShareByDave Masters:,  APR Updated:,  APR Advertorial" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailSocial connections are more important than ever at this time and people across the world are turning to technology to help them through the current crisis. Video chats on s such as Zoom, Whatsapp, Skype and Facebook Live have never been so popular as we all look to connect while stuck indoors. Thousands of fantastic charities across Britain act as hubs for their communities throughout the year to build connections and stay in touch. So now many of them are going online to continue their vital work keeping the most vulnerable people in society connected. Funds raised through The Health Lottery have long been used to help some of those most at risk from the virus right now. Here we look at four wonderful charities who come up with fun and innovative new ideas to support people... Skype comedy classes  Headspace Bolton provides stand-up comedy training sessions led by comedy professionals for people affected by mental health issues. The project aims to use humour to reduce the stigma and discrimination towards people with mental ill-health and improve opportunities for employment in the arts sector. To get around the self-isolation rules, the group are using Skype to run online podcasting, scriptwriting and comedy writing courses for members. English lessons over Whatsapp  English for Action London is a project that provides free English lessons to adult migrants who live in in Tower Hamlets . Due to COVID-, the group are experimenting with teaching via Skype and Whatsapp and are encouraging educators to share notes and teaching guides. Project members have also started calling round the students to check in with them and dropping groceries off to people who are self-isolating. Facebook Live choir sessions - with , people watching  The Rogues Shanty Chorus, from the Voice cLoud, is a local charity which aims to encourage interest in Suffolk’s unique coastal, cultural and musical heritage by exploring folk music and its associated traditions created by fishing communities. The project holds music sessions for parents of children in their early years, extra-curricular music workshops for young people, and a choir for local people. Although unable to meet as many of their members are within the vulnerable criteria, the group were determined that those who viewed the choir as a leline, wouldn’t go without. So theyaposve been hosting singalongs over Facebook live, with over  people watching. aposShed Happensapos show for aposSheddersapos  Men and women of all ages can access the Men’s Shed and She-Shed projects which involve bringing people together for a range of activities that involve conversation, craft and mutual support as well as more unusual activities such as wood turning, use of power equipment, novel crafts and outward community engagement . Staithes Shed had to close on th March but members have been keeping in touch via live video chats and some have even made their sheds available to help the community in any safe way, including erecting a cover at a surgery to protect those collecting prescriptions through a side window. Project Co-Ordinator Graham Storer said: The essence of Sheds is not what is made or done. It is the comradeship and family feel. That must will continue mainly through our online presence and electronically. We encourage our Shedders to keep on doing what they can at homeand wave to other locked down souls across the street! Sheds are people. The UK Men’s Shed Association has also started a weekly two hour programme on Wednesdays am – noon called Shed Happens” using Frome .FM which fans can access via the internet. Help tackle health inequalities in Great Britain by playing The Health Lottery

title: coronavirus fly tipping surges thousands
story: NewsCoronavirus: Fly-tipping surges as thousands of Brits use UK lockdown to clear-out homesBrits dumping rubbish during lockdown, including those taking advantage by discarding unwanted knick-knacks, clothes and furniture have been warned it will hit taxpayers in the pocketShareCommentsByRyan Merrield:,  APR Updated:,  APR NewsPiles of Recycling and general rubbish lay uncollected at Tesco Extra Store in Wembley North London " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - The Coronavirus BriefingSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe coronavirus lockdown has seen Britain become overrun with tonnes of rubbish as the closure of tips leads to a  per cent fly-tipping increase. Pictures across the UK shows piles of waste dumped on roadsides, lanes parks and fields following the closure of waste centres. Quarantined families are producing far higher levels of waste following clear outs and plenty of leftover food leading to councils across the country struggling to keep on top of disposal. Mounds of unwanted clothing and knick-knacks are also being left outside charity shops that may not re-open for months. Have you got a coronavirus story  Email webnews@mirror Only a few tips remain open but those that are operating are running with only a handful of skeleton staff. And while some people are struggling to know what to do with all the extra food waste, others have jumped on the opportunity to off load unwanted items across both rural and urban areas. Recycling centres are also largely shut for the time being and kerbside collections scaled back in many places. Photos have emerged showing the disgusting state of the problem, with rubbish piled up on roadsides, in parks and on fields, with local authorities unable to keep up. Council officials have said many people are initially looking to do the right thing by taking their rubbish to recycling centres, but on discovering them closed are dumping the waste instead. One council says the amount of waste dumped in that way has gone up three fold. West Oxfordshire District Council is pleading with residents to be more mindful with waste teams working round the clock - potentially putting themselves at risk of virus infection. They say recycling areas are having to be cleared every day by the councilaposs waste team. Cllr Norman MacRae, cabinet member for the environment, said: While we have some sympathy with residents who may have quantities of waste building up, we must emphasise that for everyoneaposs safety please refrain from dumping it in public spaces.  This places an unnecessary additional workload on our cleaning teams and is not acceptable at any time let alone the current coronavirus situation. I would further advise that these sites are not for the disposal of commercial items, they are for household recycling materials. I would remind offenders that we are monitoring the situation closely. The law has not changed and anyone caught fly-tipping will face prosecution and a large fine. A spokesman for the council said: We have not calculated the exact tonnage data as yet but we can say we have seen a threefold increase in items at key sites which is forcing us to carry out additional collections with a dedicated crew and truck.  Itaposs a mixture of items. I canapost speak for other councils but I am sure the situation is being replicated across Oxon following the closure of the household recycling centres. Councillors in Lancashire branded fly-tippers disgusting for taking advantage of the coronavirus outbreak to dump rubbish. Cllr Ray Davies, the Darwen East Liberal Democrat, said: We are in a situation where we are advised to isolate but, in some areas, they are taking advantage and simply fly tipping and not making full use of the bins. People are simply throwing bags and furniture into the back alleys and saying nothing to do with me. This is appalling. We need to be cleaner and more hygienic but here we have thoughtless residents taking advantage of the coronavirus pandemic and dumping rubbish in back alleys while the borough council staff are busy with other issues to do with the Covid- outbreak.  We are in isolation because of dirty habits, this must be a warning to all of us that we cannot keep doing this and must work together for the sake of future generations and the planet. We must help the council and take responsibility for our actions or we will be in isolation for a much longer time. Newton Street and Perry Street were cleaned by myself over the last six weeks with a lot of help from the council, but here we are again a short time later with dumping and fly-tipping all through the back streets. Alley-ways in Stoke-on-Trent are also strewn with household waste, including uneaten food and fridges. Monienne Stone, secretary of Fenton Events Board, said: Fly-tipping has been an ongoing problem in many areas of Fenton. Itaposs an urgent public health issue. People need to understand that itaposs not OK to dump litter as it endangers all our health. Thereaposs also the cost to the taxpayer to clear it up.  In Greater Manchester where recycling centres have also closed and there are fewer council workers to collect waste, fly-tipping is also on the rise. Heaps of bin bags, household furniture items and cardboard boxes are piled on streets in Collyhurst, Chadderton and Saddleworth. In a scenic spot on Brighton Road in Saddleworth, a mouldy mattress was dumped on a grass verge. Manchester City Councilaposs Executive Member for Neighbourhoods, Councillor Rabnawaz Akbar, said: Further to a fly-tipping incident on Sand Street, Collyhurst, we are currently looking into evidence provided to us by a local resident and will do everything in our power to secure the culpritaposs conviction. While this investigation is carried out, the dumped waste will also be cleared. At a time when we should all be pulling together, it is disgraceful that anybody still thinks that it is OK to fly-tip in our neighbourhoods. We will continue our enforcement efforts on behalf of Manchester residents and prosecute offenders whenever the evidence allows.  Waste is also piling up on Scottish roads, where a cooker and mattresses were abandoned at a recycling centre in Fe and rubbish spills across a grassy verge at a rural beauty spot. Selfish fly-tippers are ignoring government guidance against non-essential travel leading Fe Council to slam residentsapos irresponsible behaviour. Dawn Jamieson, safer communities team manager, said: Fly tipping is an issue. I think itaposs probably been highlighted a bit more over the past couple of weeks. What weaposve been trying to do is make people a bit more responsible. Because centres have been closed people will be thinking itaposs acceptable to be putting their rubbish and thataposs not the message weaposre trying to get across. There really isnapost an excuse at all - people are very irresponsible. With everything  going on at the moment, how people are finding the time to go out and go against the governmentaposs advice to make unnecessary journeys and dump rubbish is beyond me.  Ken Gourlay, head of assets and transportation and environment at Fe Council, said: Unfortunately, in these challenging times when council services are already under additional pressure, the misuse of recycling points and fly tipping are issues. Everyone is responsible for their own waste and must dispose of their rubbish responsibly. Recycling points are still available at supermarkets and shopping centres, but residents are requested not to make special visits to them, in line with government guidance, but to use them while doing their essential shopping. If your supermarket has recycling facilities and you are travelling there anyway, please dispose of your recycling responsibly. Waste and recycling should not be placed beside the bins at recycling points or communal bins.  We apologise for any inconvenience this may cause, but we ask that everyone follows the governmentaposs strict instructions at this time and not make any non-essential journeys and undertake non-essential activities. We are working hard to ensure that we continue to pick up domestic bins from the kerb, so that thereaposs no need to travel. We ask that only bins that need emptied - more than half full - are put out for collection to help relieve pressure on our reduced collection teams. With the closure of the household waste and recycling centres, and the suspension of the bulky uplt service, residents should ensure that large items intended for disposal are stored safely away from communal areas.

title: family shed tears life saving
story: NewsFamily shed tears for le-saving daughter crowned worlds youngest organ donorEXCLUSIVE Hope Lee, of Newmarket. Cambridgeshire, only lived for  minutes but still made a impact on the world when her kidneys and liver cells were donated to a woman in her late twentiesShareCommentsByLouie Smith:,  APR NewsHope Lee lived for just  minutes " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWe will use your email address to send you newsletters. Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe sister and twin brother of the world’s youngest organ donor, Hope Lee, proudly hold up a certicate honouring the tot’s gt. Madie, nine, and four-year-old Josh showed off the honour that was sent to parents Drew Lee and Emma Thomas from the Guinness World Records. Hope died in November  shortly after she was born and her kidneys and liver cells were donated. Drew, , said of the certicates the family received: “I actually burst into tears when I opened the letter. “It was quite an emotional moment, to me this has finalised something. “Even though Hope only lived for  minutes she is still making her mark on the world. She will never be forgotten. After I’m gone someone will look at these books and read her name.”  Emma, , added: “Receiving the letter was a bit of a shock and opening it brought tears to my eyes.” The certicates read: “The youngest organ donor is Hope Lee, of Newmarket, UK, who donated her kidneys and liver cells just  minutes after she was born on  November .” Drew and Emma found out in the early stages of pregnancy Hope had the brain condition anencephaly and would not survive. But they refused to abort her after being inspired by the story of another tiny donor. Teddy Houlston lived for just  minutes before he donated his organs in . Hope’s kidneys were given to a woman in her late s.  Despite being as small as hazelnuts, the organs grew rapidly and are now of an adult size. Josh is also going from strength to strength. Drew said: “He’s a lovely little boy, very caring and loving, he’s just so adorable. “He knows he had a little sister and can recognise her photo. He’s taken finding out about Hope really well.” Drew and Emma have always spoken in support of the Mirror’s successful campaign for the ­introduction of Max and Kiera’s Law. The couple understand a doctor from Addenbrooke’s Hospital, Cambridge, who was involved with their daughter, submitted her name for the record.  Drew said: “Hope is part of history now and has left her mark on the world. In many ways we are still grieving but the world record certicates are another step towards closure.” The couple have since split. Emma still lives in Newmarket and Drew at nearby Mildenhall. Max and Keira’s Law is named after a boy who received a heart ­transplant and the girl who donated it to him. Keira Ball, from Devon, was only nine when she died in a car accident. Her dad agreed for her organs to be donated and she saved four lives, including that of Max Johnson, of ­Winsford, Cheshire. The nine-year-old had been kept alive with a mechanical pump and would have died without the transplant.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email Britainaposs public health officials failed to draw up plans for mass community testing, despite warnings about coronavirus from the World Health Organisation.Such measures were never even discussed as emergency planners wrongly believed a new strain of flu, rather than Covid-, would be the next health issue in the UK, a senior government adviser has claimed. WHO had warned ministers, as well as Public Health, Cabinet and Department of Health officials that community testing could slow the spread of the virus.“That may have been a mistake,” Professor Graham Medley, chairman of SPI-M, official government advisers for infectious diseases, told The .The admissions by Whitehall officials that mass testing did not figure in discussions comes as ministers are now facing questions on the effectiveness of defences used in the pandemic. The likes of Germany and South Korea have been able to test hundreds of thousands of their citizens quickly in contrast to Britain which is still struggling to keep up. PHE has been slammed for failing to set up laboratories across the UK meaning frontline NHS staff canapost get virus tests. One official said on Thursday it was down to the health agencyaposs complete control freakery which led to the failure. While Prof Medley said government modellers were unable to keep track of the virusapos spread, as a result. “The current problem is based upon the fact that we didn’t invest in preparedness before all this happened, he admitted.  The professor said because so much focus was put on the flu - which doesnapost require mass testing - the government was ill prepared, with PHE central to the whole thing. He said flu pandemics are a regular occurrence but other viruses like HIV, SARS, Mers and Ebola all had the potential at one time to become major outbreaks. “In hindsight I would have brought in  more laboratory roles in October. He went on to say the issue was the government being reluctant to invest millions of pounds in something unless it was in front of them at the time. Prof Medley said testing is crucial to get a grip on the situation while the best data we currently have is from how many people have been hospitalised and how many have died. However, he admitted UK officials have been well aware of how prepared South Koreaaposs mass public testing programmes are following the Sars epidemic in . Even so, the UK government’s preparations also appear to conflict with official guidance on bird flu issued to countries by the World Health Organisation. The WHO had advised countries to prepare mass testing in  in response to bird flu though these were also ignored in Britain. Thehas previously reported how the government kept the terrying results of a secret outbreak test in  under wraps. Exercise Cygnus found Britain would be quickly overwhelmed by a severe outbreak due to critical bed shortages, morgue capacity and PPE - but as a result mass testing was still not deemed necessary. The source said next time the government would take a dferent approach in relation to mass testing. But claimed PHE and ministers should have reached out and got this thing going earlier once other countries began their own testing programmes.

Please see ourPrivacy Noticefor more information on how we use your data and your data protection rights.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid Email One of the most important things we can do to beat the coronavirus that is sweeping through Britain and the rest of the world is to make sure we stay at home.In a bid to slow the spread of Covid- to enable the NHS to cope people are being asked to only leave their homes when they need to get essential supplies or food or for exercise once a day. Gathering in groups of biggers than two people is now banned, including friends and family and people are being told to work from home. Police have now been given the power to fine people who go out for drives for walks and everyone is being told to keep at least six feet away from others. Only essential shops, like supermarkets and pharmacies, are open with others, like hairdressers, pubs, restaurants and theatres now closed until further notice. But even though weaposre all being told to keep our distance from each other, it doesnapost mean you canapost have a social le during the coronavirus crisis. Thanks to smart phones and the internet there are ever increasing ways of keeping in touch. Hereaposs how you can maintain a social le during the coronavirus lockdown. Virtual pub The days of nipping to the pub for a pint with your pals might be over for now - but that doesnapost mean that you have to give up the boozer entirely. There are a raft of apps that let you have a drink with your family and friends, and you can even play pub games.One of the most popular around the world and in the UK is the Houseparty app, which has fast become one of the most downloaded apps in the globe.Calls can include up to eight people on the video chat app, meaning you have have a bevvie with your mates face-to-face . It comes with a range of features and you can even have your own pub quiz. Other ways of hanging out on video calls with your friends and family include Zoom, FaceTime, Teams and WhatsApp. Go to a gig The lockdown includes celebs too - and many of them are putting their spare time to good use by staging shows from the comfort of their own homes. From Chris Martin to Gary Barlow and John Legend to Elton John, all the big names are getting in on the act. To make them even more fun, the concerts are all free . Go to a workout class Joe Wicks might be the most famous fitness expert currently streaming regular workouts but the nationaaposs PE teacher certainly isnapost the only one. You could even use the lockdown to help you get fit in the time before normal le resumes.Joe is streaming his class at am every week day and donating all profits from the upsurge to his YouTube channel to the NHS.He also has some armchair exercises for seniors. But there are many others out there, including former breakfast TV favourite Mr Motivator. If getting fit while learning a new skill is more up your street then you could try a dance class. Andsomething super aerobic isnapost really your thing there are a raft of other classes available from yoga to pilates. Have a film night Yes, cinemas are closed but itaposs never been easier to watch a good movie.With Netflix, Amazon Prime, Apple and now Disney Plus streaming services there is plenty to chose from.Several of the major studios are now also offering their new releases straight for rental from the comfort of your living room - so all you need is a bucket of popcorn. A trip to the theatre It seems the stars of the silver screen are getting as restless as us during the vital lockdown. Gal Gadot might have been roundly mocked after getting all her pals together to have a sing-a-long about how tough they were all finding self-isolation - but there are many other options out there. British national treasure, Dame Judi Dench, has come up with a great way of bringing theatre into our homes through our mobile phones, tablets and computers. She, along with some pals, has recited a powerful extract from Shakespeare.
